==History==
 
==History==
    −
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. +
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]]. However the stoics did not delve into the topic with the same rational riggor as Aristotle in his Nicomachean ethics, the product of his own lectures and discourses with his teacher Plato, and other Athenian intellectuals.
     
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
 
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
